title: How to check monitor display resolution - Quora

response.answer_text: If you are using Windows, right click on the desktop and select ‘Display settings’. On the window that opens, scroll down and there should be a drop-down box labeled ‘Resolution’. If you click the drop-down, you will see the resolutions that your monitor supports.  The resolution marked ‘Recommended’ is the resolution of your monitor. Here is a wiki-how article with details for Macintosh as well.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Louie S. Lalic

response.answer_text: It’s measured by number of pixels across the screen. SD 720 HD 1920 UHD 3,840 4k 4,096 So… if you have a 36″ display, the size doesn’t change with different resolutions, but the number of pixels change. If your input is created at HD 1920, and you play it back at UDH, it’ll take those 1920 pixels and display them stretched across 3, 840 pixels. Since it’s double, it’ll look pretty good….actually very good. But of you have SD 720 and play it over 4,096 pixels it’ll look bad. So resolution is the number of pixels the display has… not per inch like printing because… an 80 inch UHD has the SAME number of pixels as a 36 inch UHD display.
